chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect Osgood-Schlatter disease?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If there are no features suggestive of another cause of knee pain, Osgood-Schlatter disease may be diagnosed clinically.

  • Exclude an alternative cause for knee pain:
    • Clinical features associated with serious alternative diagnoses include trauma, systemic symptoms (such as fever, weight loss, or sweats), bone or joint pain elsewhere, night pain, pain after rest, and referred pain.
    • If a serious alternative cause is suspected, urgently refer for specialist assessment or arrange investigations as appropriate.
  • Typically, pain associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease starts in adolescence and is:
    • Localized to the tibial tuberosity.
    • Gradual in onset and initially mild and intermittent, but may progress to become severe and continuous.
    • Unilateral (but may be bilateral in up to 30% of people).
    • Relieved by rest and made worse by kneeling and activity, such as running, jumping, or kneeling.
  • Findings associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease on examination include:
    • Tenderness over the tibial tuberosity.
    • Pain provoked by resisted knee extension.
    • Tightness of the quadriceps and hamstrings.
    • Swelling or bony enlargement of the tibial tuberosity.
    • A normal passive range of movement.
    • The absence of effusion.
  • Do not routinely X-ray the knee to confirm a diagnosis of Osgood-Schlatter disease.
    • If undertaken, knee X-ray in Osgood-Schlatter disease may be normal or may demonstrate anterior soft tissue swelling, thickening of the patellar tendon, fragmentation of the tibial tubercle, or ossicle. Ultrasound and MRI may also be used for imaging in secondary care.
    • Imaging (with urgency dependant on the clinical situation) may be considered if free ossicles or alternative diagnoses are suspected – seek specialist advice if unsure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect Osgood-Schlatter disease are based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011; Circi, 2017; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020; Rathleff, 2020].

Excluding an alternative cause for knee pain

  • The recommendation to exclude an alternative cause for knee pain is based on expert opinion in review articles [Weiler, 2011; Circi, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].

Clinical features of Osgood-Schlatter disease

  • The information on typical clinical features of Osgood-Schlatter disease are based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011; Circi, 2017; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020; Rathleff, 2020].
  • Osgood-Schlatter disease is a clinical diagnosis that can be made on the basis of history and examination findings alone, provided there are no features suggesting a more serious underlying cause [Weiler, 2011].

Knee X-ray not routinely recommended

  • The recommendation that the diagnosis is usually clinical and knee X-ray is not routinely needed if symptoms and signs are typical is based on expert opinion in review articles that also outline characteristic X-ray findings [Circi, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].
  • A case series of 76 children (94 knees) diagnosed on the basis of clinical features and X-ray abnormalities of the tibial tuberosity found there was no relationship between the clinical findings and radiographic severity, suggesting that routine knee X-ray lacks the sensitivity to reliably diagnose Osgood-Schlatter disease [Hanada et al, 2012].
